lenders.loan_because: our business, needs financial support, we have fishpond located in Hagonoy Bulacan, it need more capitals, to support our expenses.
lenders.occupational_info:
I am currently working as a College Instructor at National University Philippines and I am managing our family business, fishpond in Hagonoy Bulacan. I learn that kiva is an organization that lend money, I would like to take this opportunity to nurture our business, it needs more capital and payment in other expenses.  We are also selling our product for those who want to buy and sell,  our seafood are all live and fresh like  prawn, crab, milkfish. Hagonoy is the capital of seafood prawn in the Philippines most of the people in Hagonoy work all their lives in sea and fish ponds, neighbor work with camaraderie, support each other in times of crisis. Rest assure that the money that will be lend will be use properly. Thank you so much!

Jennifer R. Dela Cruz

email address: jennie_delacruz@yahoo.com
639166888320

lenders.name: Mary
lenders.loan_because:
I believe in helping people to pursue their dreams. I am studying Judaism and in the religion there is the concept of  Tzedakah. The word "tzedakah" is derived from the Hebrew root Tzadei-Dalet-Qof, meaning righteousness, justice or fairness, giving is not viewed as a generous, magnanimous act; it is simply an act of justice and righteousness, the performance of a duty, giving those in need their due.

Certain kinds of tzedakah are considered more meritorious than others. The Talmud describes these different levels of tzedakah, and Rambam organized them into a list. The levels of charity, from the least meritorious to the most meritorious, are:

Giving begrudgingly
Giving less that you should, but giving it cheerfully.
Giving after being asked
Giving before being asked
Giving when you do not know the recipient's identity, but the recipient knows your identity
Giving when you know the recipient's identity, but the recipient doesn't know your identity
Giving when neither party knows the other's identity
Enabling the recipient to become self-reliant

I love kiva because it is all about helping people become self-reliant!

lenders.occupational_info: We are children who attend child care in Bonnie's home while our parents are at work.

lenders.name: Robert
lenders.loan_because: I feel that this is an even better way of helping people in need than donating to charity.  It helps people grow rather than patching problems temporarily with short term aid.  Borrowers are required to document how the loan helped them.  Also, the microfinancing institutions are actually interviewing borrowers face to face and appropriately assessing risk.  This is something banks in the US neglected to do and is one of the reasons we faced a recession.  I loan because I think Kiva and the microfinancing institutions have stepped in and filled a huge hole in the way capital is disbursed.  They are giving directly to small businesses.  In the US right now the way we do this is we give a lot of money to the big banks and cross our fingers and hope that they will give to small businesses.  If they don't then we try to regulate them.  Kiva is addressing need directly at the source of the problem.  I like it!
lenders.occupational_info: I write computer programs that make it easier for people to find information about companies in financial databases.  It is similar to implementing Google for the financial industry.
